possibleInjuries.name: Deltoid Strain (Front)
possibleInjuries.description: A pull, tear, or over-stretching of the muscle fibers at the front of the shoulder.
commonCauses: Overuse from pushing exercises (e.g., bench press)

possibleInjuries.name: Front Deltoid Tendinopathy
possibleInjuries.description: Degeneration or inflammation of the tendon connecting the front deltoid to the bone.

possibleInjuries.name: Deltoid Strain (Side)
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear in the muscle fibers on the side of the shoulder, responsible for lifting the arm sideways.
commonCauses: Direct impact to the side of the shoulder

possibleInjuries.name: Deltoid Strain (Rear)
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear in the muscle fibers at the back of the shoulder.
commonCauses: Sports involving high-speed arm movements (e.g., tennis serve)

possibleInjuries.name: Rotator Cuff Tear
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or full tear in one or more of the four tendons (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis) that stabilize the shoulder.
commonCauses: Heavy lifting with a jerking motion

possibleInjuries.name: Shoulder Impingement / Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons as they pass through the narrow subacromial space, often getting 'pinched'.

possibleInjuries.name: Shoulder Bursitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation of the bursa, a small fluid-filled sac that cushions the tendons from the bone.

possibleInjuries.name: AC Joint Sprain (Shoulder Separation)
possibleInjuries.description: An injury to the ligaments that connect the collarbone (clavicle) to the shoulder blade (acromion). Graded from mild to severe.
commonCauses: Direct fall onto the point of the shoulder
Hard impact from sports (e.g., hockey, football)

possibleInjuries.name: Shoulder Dislocation / Instability
possibleInjuries.description: The head of the upper arm bone (humerus) is forcibly removed from its shallow socket (glenoid).
commonCauses: Traumatic impact from a fall or collision
Forceful, extreme rotation of the arm

possibleInjuries.name: Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)
possibleInjuries.description: A condition characterized by stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint, where the joint capsule becomes thick and tight.
commonCauses: Prolonged immobilization after injury or surgery
More common in people with diabetes

possibleInjuries.name: Trapezius Strain / Myofascial Pain
possibleInjuries.description: Overstretching or microscopic tearing of the muscle fibers, often resulting in muscle knots (trigger points), stiffness, and tension headaches.
commonCauses: Poor posture (e.g., forward head posture, 'text neck')
Lifting heavy objects improperly (e.g., heavy shrugs)
Carrying a heavy bag on one shoulder

possibleInjuries.name: Nerve Entrapment
possibleInjuries.description: A tight upper trapezius muscle can sometimes compress nearby nerves (like the accessory nerve), leading to pain, weakness, or tingling.
commonCauses: Previous injury leading to scar tissue

possibleInjuries.name: Middle Trapezius Strain
possibleInjuries.description: Pain or strain located in the region between the shoulder blades, often associated with repetitive arm movements.
commonCauses: Prolonged slouching while sitting at a desk
Weakness leading to overuse during overhead activities

possibleInjuries.name: Lower Trapezius Strain or Weakness
possibleInjuries.description: Pain or dysfunction in the lower shoulder blade area. Weakness in this muscle is a very common contributor to shoulder impingement and poor posture.
commonCauses: Muscle imbalance (dominant upper traps and chest)

possibleInjuries.name: Rhomboid Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull, tear, or over-stretching of the muscle fibers, often felt as a sharp or aching pain between the upper shoulder blade and the spine.

possibleInjuries.name: Rhomboid Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear in the larger rhomboid muscle, causing pain, knots (trigger points), and stiffness between the shoulder blades.
commonCauses: Improper form during lifting (e.g., deadlifts, rows)

possibleInjuries.name: Snapping Scapula Syndrome (Scapulothoracic Bursitis)
possibleInjuries.description: A grinding, popping, or 'snapping' sensation of the shoulder blade against the rib cage, often caused by muscle imbalance (tight/weak rhomboids) or bursitis.

possibleInjuries.name: Teres Minor Strain (Rotator Cuff Tear)
possibleInjuries.description: A stretch, pull, or tear of the teres minor muscle or its tendon. As a key rotator cuff muscle, it helps with external rotation (rotating the arm outward) and stabilizing the shoulder.
commonCauses: Forceful, sudden external rotation (e.g., stopping a throw)
Repetitive overhead activities (e.g., pitching, tennis serve)

possibleInjuries.name: Teres Minor Tendinopathy / Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration (tendinopathy) of the teres minor tendon, often where it attaches to the humerus.
commonCauses: Chronic overuse from repetitive external rotation
Poor biomechanics in throwing or overhead sports

possibleInjuries.name: Quadrilateral Space Syndrome
possibleInjuries.description: Compression of the axillary nerve and an artery in a small space (the quadrilateral space) bordered by the teres minor, teres major, humerus, and triceps. This can cause vague shoulder pain and weakness.
commonCauses: Thickening (fibrosis) of the teres minor from overuse
Direct trauma to the posterior shoulder

possibleInjuries.name: Pectoral Strain (Upper)
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear of the muscle fibers in the upper portion of the chest, often near where it attaches to the arm.

possibleInjuries.name: Pectoral Tear / Rupture
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or complete tear of the main pectoral muscle or its tendon, most often where it attaches to the upper arm bone (humerus). This is a severe injury.
commonCauses: Sudden, high-force contraction, especially during a bench press (often on the eccentric/lowering phase)
Direct trauma to the chest or armpit area
Steroid use can weaken tendons, increasing risk

possibleInjuries.name: Pectoral Strain (Sternal)
possibleInjuries.description: A less severe pull or micro-tear in the main belly of the pectoral muscle.
commonCauses: Improper form on dips or bench press

possibleInjuries.name: Pectoralis Minor Syndrome
possibleInjuries.description: A condition where the pec minor muscle becomes tight and overactive, compressing the brachial plexus (nerves) and blood vessels that run beneath it, causing pain, numbness, or tingling in the arm, shoulder, and hand.
commonCauses: Chronic poor posture (rounded shoulders, forward head)
Muscle imbalance from overtraining chest and undertraining back

possibleInjuries.name: Pec Minor Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A strain of the small, deep muscle that pulls the shoulder blade forward and down.
commonCauses: Overuse in activities like swimming or throwing

subMuscles.name: Triceps Muscle Belly (Long, Lateral, & Medial Heads)

possibleInjuries.name: Triceps Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull, tear, or over-stretching of the muscle fibers in one of the three heads (long, lateral, or medial) of the triceps.
commonCauses: Forceful, sudden extension of the elbow (e.g., throwing)
Overuse from repetitive pushing (e.g., push-ups, dips, bench press)
Direct blow to the back of the arm

possibleInjuries.name: Triceps Tendinitis / Tendinopathy
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the triceps tendon, which attaches the muscle to the point of the elbow (olecranon).
commonCauses: Repetitive elbow extension activities (e.g., hammering, weightlifting)
Sudden increase in training volume for pushing exercises
Direct trauma to the elbow point

possibleInjuries.name: Triceps Tendon Rupture
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or complete tear of the triceps tendon from the elbow bone. This is a severe injury causing pain, swelling, and inability to straighten the elbow against resistance.
commonCauses: A sudden, forceful contraction (e.g., trying to catch a heavy falling weight)
A fall onto an outstretched hand
A direct, sharp blow to the tendon

possibleInjuries.name: Olecranon Bursitis (Student's Elbow)
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation of the bursa (a small, fluid-filled sac) that lies between the point of the elbow and the skin. While not a muscle injury, it's directly related to the triceps insertion area.
commonCauses: Prolonged pressure on the elbow (e.g., leaning on a desk)
A direct blow to the tip of the elbow

possibleInjuries.name: Biceps Tendinitis (Proximal)
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or irritation of the long head of the biceps tendon as it passes through the bicipital groove in the shoulder.
commonCauses: Overuse in pulling or curling exercises
Often co-occurs with shoulder impingement or rotator cuff issues

possibleInjuries.name: Proximal Biceps Tendon Rupture (Popeye Muscle)
possibleInjuries.description: A tear of the long head of the biceps tendon from its attachment at the shoulder, often causing the muscle belly to 'ball up'.
commonCauses: Sudden, heavy load (e.g., catching a heavy falling object)
Degenerative wear and tear over time
Chronic tendinitis that weakens the tendon

possibleInjuries.name: SLAP Tear
possibleInjuries.description: An injury to the labrum (cartilage) of the shoulder socket, specifically where the long head of the biceps tendon attaches (Superior Labrum Anterior to Posterior).
commonCauses: Acute heavy lifting or jerking motions

possibleInjuries.name: Biceps Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull, tear, or over-stretching of the muscle fibers in the main belly of the biceps.
commonCauses: Overuse from repetitive curling or lifting

possibleInjuries.name: Distal Biceps Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the biceps tendon where it attaches to the radius bone in the forearm.
commonCauses: Repetitive, forceful supination (twisting the forearm palm-up)
Overuse from curling or rock climbing

possibleInjuries.name: Distal Biceps Tendon Rupture
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or complete tear of the biceps tendon from its attachment at the elbow. This is a severe injury often causing a 'pop' and weakness.
commonCauses: A sudden, forceful eccentric load (e.g., trying to catch a heavy box)

possibleInjuries.name: Latissimus Dorsi Strain (Pulled Lat)
possibleInjuries.description: A stretch, pull, or tear of the muscle fibers in the large, fan-shaped muscle of the back. This is the most common lat injury.
commonCauses: Sudden, forceful arm adduction (bringing arm to side)

possibleInjuries.name: Myofascial Pain Syndrome
possibleInjuries.description: Development of painful knots (trigger points) within the lat muscle or its surrounding fascia, often referring pain to the shoulder, armpit, or lower back.

possibleInjuries.name: Latissimus Dorsi Tendinopathy
possibleInjuries.description: Degeneration or inflammation of the lat tendon, causing pain in the armpit, front, or back of the shoulder where it attaches to the humerus (upper arm bone).
commonCauses: Poor mechanics in overhead sports (e.g., throwing)

possibleInjuries.name: Latissimus Dorsi Tendon Rupture / Tear
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or, more rarely, complete tear of the tendon where the lat muscle attaches to the upper arm bone. This is a severe injury.
commonCauses: High-force, eccentric contraction (e.g., lowering a heavy lat pull-down)
Traumatic injury in sports (e.g., rock climbing, gymnastics, wrestling)

possibleInjuries.name: Medial Epicondylitis (Golfer's Elbow)
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the tendons that attach the forearm flexor muscles to the inner part of the elbow (medial epicondyle).
commonCauses: Improper form on pulling or curling exercises

possibleInjuries.name: Flexor Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear of the muscle fibers on the front (palm side) of the forearm.
commonCauses: Overuse from gripping sports (e.g., rock climbing)

possibleInjuries.name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
possibleInjuries.description: Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist, often due to inflamed flexor tendons. Causes numbness, tingling, and weakness.

possibleInjuries.name: Lateral Epicondylitis (Tennis Elbow)
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the tendons that attach the forearm extensor muscles to the outer part of the elbow (lateral epicondyle).
commonCauses: Repetitive gripping and wrist extension (e.g., tennis backhand, using tools)
Improper form on pulling exercises (e.g., rows, pull-ups)

possibleInjuries.name: Extensor Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear of the muscle fibers on the back (knuckle side) of the forearm.
commonCauses: Overuse in activities like motorcycling or racquet sports
Improper form on reverse wrist curls

possibleInjuries.name: Lumbar Muscle Strain (Pulled Lower Back)
possibleInjuries.description: A stretching, pull, or tear of the muscle fibers (often the erector spinae) or ligaments in the lower back, leading to pain, stiffness, and muscle spasms.
commonCauses: Lifting a heavy object improperly (e.g., rounding the back)
Muscle fatigue from prolonged poor posture

possibleInjuries.name: Myofascial Pain Syndrome
possibleInjuries.description: The development of painful 'trigger points' or knots in the lower back muscles, which can cause localized pain or refer pain to other areas like the hips.

possibleInjuries.name: QL Strain / Tightness
possibleInjuries.description: A strain or, more commonly, deep tightness and trigger points in the QL muscle, often causing a deep, aching pain on one side of the lower back.
commonCauses: Lifting an object from an awkward side position
Prolonged sitting with poor posture (e.g., leaning to one side)

possibleInjuries.name: Gluteus Medius Syndrome (Referral Pain)
possibleInjuries.description: While technically a hip muscle, tightness, weakness, or trigger points in the gluteus medius (upper/side glute) very commonly refer pain directly to the lower back.
commonCauses: Running or hiking with poor mechanics
Sleeping on one side without support

possibleInjuries.name: Gluteus Maximus Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear of the large glute muscle fibers. Causes pain in the buttock during contraction, such as climbing stairs or running.
commonCauses: Improper form during lunges or deadlifts

possibleInjuries.name: Deep Gluteal Syndrome (Piriformis Syndrome)
possibleInjuries.description: Pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks that radiates down the leg. This is often caused by the deep piriformis muscle compressing the sciatic nerve.
commonCauses: Muscle tightness in the deep glute
Overuse from activities like long-distance running

possibleInjuries.name: Gluteus Medius Tendinopathy
possibleInjuries.description: Degeneration or inflammation of the gluteus medius tendon where it attaches to the hip bone. This often causes pain on the outside of the hip.
commonCauses: Muscle imbalances such as weak glutes

possibleInjuries.name: Gluteus Medius Strain or Trigger Points
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or the development of tight, painful muscle knots. This can refer pain to the lower back or down the leg.
commonCauses: Poor biomechanics during walking or running

possibleInjuries.name: Gluteus Minimus Tendinopathy or Tear
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or tearing of the deepest glute muscle tendon, causing pain on the outside of the hip, similar to gluteus medius issues.

possibleInjuries.name: Trigger Points (Referral Pain)
possibleInjuries.description: Painful knots in this muscle can send sharp, sciatic-like pain down the side or back of the leg, often mimicking a true sciatica condition.

subMuscles.name: Hamstring Muscle Belly (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus)

possibleInjuries.name: Hamstring Strain / Pulled Hamstring
possibleInjuries.description: A stretch, pull, or tear in one or more of the hamstring muscles. Graded 1 (mild) to 3 (complete rupture).

possibleInjuries.name: Myofascial Pain / Trigger Points
possibleInjuries.description: The development of tight, painful knots (trigger points) in the hamstring muscles, which can cause local pain or refer pain to the knee.

possibleInjuries.name: Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the hamstring tendons where they attach to the 'sit bone' (ischial tuberosity). Often causes a deep ache in the buttock.

possibleInjuries.name: Proximal Hamstring Tendon Avulsion
possibleInjuries.description: A severe injury where the hamstring tendon tears completely away from the sit bone, sometimes pulling a small piece of bone with it.
commonCauses: Sudden, forceful contraction (e.g., water skiing, sprinting)

possibleInjuries.name: Distal Hamstring Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation of the hamstring tendons (either on the inner or outer side) just behind the knee.

possibleInjuries.name: Quadriceps Strain (Pulled Quad)
possibleInjuries.description: A stretch, pull, or tear in one of the four quadriceps muscles (rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, vastus intermedius).

possibleInjuries.name: Quadriceps Contusion (Corked Thigh)
possibleInjuries.description: A deep bruise in the muscle caused by a direct, hard impact, leading to internal bleeding, swelling, and pain.
commonCauses: Direct blow from sports (e.g., a knee or helmet)

possibleInjuries.name: Patellar Tendinitis (Jumper's Knee)
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or degeneration of the tendon connecting the kneecap (patella) to the shinbone (tibia). Causes pain just below the kneecap.
commonCauses: Sudden increase in running or squatting

possibleInjuries.name: Quadriceps Tendinopathy / Rupture
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation or a tear (partial or complete) of the tendon that connects the quadriceps muscles to the top of the kneecap.
commonCauses: A fall onto a bent knee

possibleInjuries.name: Hip Flexor Strain (Rectus Femoris)
possibleInjuries.description: A pull or tear of the rectus femoris muscle (the only quad muscle that crosses the hip) or its tendon where it attaches at the hip. Causes pain in the front of the hip or high on the thigh.

possibleInjuries.name: Calf Strain (Tennis Leg)
possibleInjuries.description: A sudden, sharp pain from a tear in the gastrocnemius muscle, often the medial (inner) head.

possibleInjuries.name: Soleus Strain
possibleInjuries.description: A deeper, often nagging or aching pain in the calf, which can build up over time. Less sudden than a gastrocnemius strain.
commonCauses: Repetitive activities with a bent knee (e.g., cycling)

possibleInjuries.name: Achilles Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation, stiffness, and pain in the large tendon connecting the calf muscles to the heel bone.
commonCauses: Repetitive stress from running or jumping

possibleInjuries.name: Achilles Tendon Rupture
possibleInjuries.description: A partial or complete tear of the Achilles tendon, often felt as a sudden, sharp 'pop' or 'kick' in the back of the ankle.

possibleInjuries.name: Anterior Shin Splints
possibleInjuries.description: Pain, inflammation, and tenderness along the front (anterior) edge of the shinbone (tibia).
commonCauses: Sudden increase in running mileage or intensity
Weakness or overuse of the shin muscle

possibleInjuries.name: Anterior Tibialis Tendinitis
possibleInjuries.description: Inflammation of the anterior tibialis tendon, typically causing pain on the front of the ankle, especially when lifting the foot up (dorsiflexion).
commonCauses: Overuse from activities like hiking or running (especially uphill)
Friction from tight shoes or boots

possibleInjuries.name: Compartment Syndrome (Anterior)
possibleInjuries.description: A serious condition where pressure builds up in the anterior muscle compartment, cutting off blood flow. Causes severe pain, tightness, numbness, or weakness in the shin and foot.
commonCauses: Acute: A direct, hard impact to the shin
Chronic (Exercise-Induced): Muscle swelling from repetitive exercise (e.g., running) in a tight fascial compartment
